questions.question_text_1: The p-value of the chi-square goodness of fit test represents _________
question_texts: The p-value of the chi-square goodness of fit test represents _________

options.option_text: The chance of observing the sample when the null hypothesis is false
The chance of observing the sample when the alternative hypothesis is true
The chance of observing the sample at the specified level of significance
The chance of observing the sample when the null hypothesis is true
The chance of observing the sample when the alternative hypothesis is false
Yes, Swami ji is a Genius and has selected the correct variable to be added tothe model
No, Swami ji is just a Show-off and has not chosen the correct variable toadded to the model
Cannot say, as sufficient information is not available

questions.question_text_1: In a conjoint problem with 5 products and 2 attributes, how many unique pair-wise preferences are possible?
question_texts: In a conjoint problem with 5 products and 2 attributes, how many unique pair-wise preferences are possible?

questions.question_text_1: If the attribute values in the conjoint analysis is a continuous variable and the data is collected in a pairwise order, then what approach can be used:
question_texts: If the attribute values in the conjoint analysis is a continuous variable and the data is collected in a pairwise order, then what approach can be used:

questions.question_text_1: The part worth can be defined as:
question_texts: The part worth can be defined as:

options.option_text: The utility for that level of attribute
Utility for separate parts of the products
Both Level utilities & The utility for that level of attribute

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are required to build an empirical distribution?
question_texts: Which of the following are required to build an empirical distribution?

questions.question_text_1: There are 6 business units and you are using the DEA to compare them. You solve the LP for business unit 5. You find from the constraint expression that business unit 5 has obtained an efficiency of 0.7 and business unit 6 has obtained an efficiency of 1 with the optimal weights of business unit 5. Which of the following statements is correct?
question_texts: There are 6 business units and you are using the DEA to compare them. You solve the LP for business unit 5. You find from the constraint expression that business unit 5 has obtained an efficiency of 0.7 and business unit 6 has obtained an efficiency of 1 with the optimal weights of business unit 5. Which of the following statements is correct?

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true:
question_texts: Which of the following is true:

options.option_text: Productive efficiency focuses on maximizing the given output under givenconstraints by optimally allocating the products.
Productive efficiency frontiers are all combinations of outputs such that theproduction of one unit cannot be increased without sacrificing the other.
Organizations that find themselves on the Economic frontier are calledefficient economic units.
DEA focuses on technology to improve productive efficiency.

questions.question_text_1: “BA Books” sells its popular book titled “PJs” to the learners in the BSc programme. The demand for the book is modelled by a curve which is captured as 23000-10*P1 (where “P1” is the selling price of the book). With this information, answer the given subquestions.
question_texts: “BA Books” sells its popular book titled “PJs” to the learners in the BSc programme. The demand for the book is modelled by a curve which is captured as 23000-10*P1 (where “P1” is the selling price of the book). With this information, answer the given subquestions.

questions.question_text_1: If the aim is to maximize revenue, then what should be the value of P1?  NOTE: Enter your answer to the nearest integer.
question_texts: If the aim is to maximize revenue, then what should be the value of P1?  NOTE: Enter your answer to the nearest integer.

questions.question_text_1: Suppose a factory manufactures products on four machines A, B, C and D. Suppose 60% of total output comes from machine A, 22% of total output comes from machine B, 7% of total output comes from machine C and rest are from machine D. From the past data, it is known that 12% of products by machine A are defectives, 17% of products by machine B are defectives, 8% of products by machine C are defectives and 10% of products by machine D are defective. With this information, answer the given subquestions

questions.question_text_1: There are 6 business units where we measure the efficiency based on two outputs and one input. You are solving the optimization problem for business unit 6 and find that the efficiency is 0.75. You find that the dual variables corresponding to the constraints of business units 4 and 5 are non-zero and the dual variables corresponding to the constraints of other units are zero. The dual variables corresponding to the constraints of business units 4 and 5 are 0.35 and 0.4 respectively. You are given the following table where sales and loyal customers are the two outputs.

questions.question_text_1: The BA discourse is often cluttered with queries / requests related to solutions for Past Year Question Papers (PYQP). The course instructor, Dr. Milo, had been informing that students need to put in effort to find solutions by searching the discourse. However, the results seem to disappointing. Therefore, Dr. Milo wanted to do a few basic analytics on discourse behaviour of students. Past student data was collected for the analysis.  Past data was collected for the BA terms in Jan-2022, May-2022, Sep-2022, Jan-2023, May-2023 and Sep-2023. For each term, 100 randomly selected unique student IDs were sampled. Of the 100 student IDs, 50 were “Male” and the remaining were “Female”. The learners in the discourse have either “followed the instructions” or “not followed the instructions” or “have not accessed the discourse at all” (these three are referred to as access categories). Specifically, for the sample data in the different terms (in sequence of earliest term to later term i.e. Jan-2022 to Sep-2023) it was observed that  1. For the Male sample: 20, 30, 25, 45, 25 and 35 had not followed the instructions (respectively in each term i.e 20 male learners had followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) 2. For the Male sample: 2, 10, 5, 4, 5 and 3 had not accessed discourse at all (respectively in each term i.e 2 male learners had not accessed discourse at all in Jan-2022 term and so on) 3. For the female sample: 15, 22, 32, 25, 20 and 20 had followed the instructions (respectively in each term i.e 15 female learners had followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) and the rest of the learners in the respective samples had not followed the instructions  Moreover, Dr. Milo assumes that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Normally distributed with a mean of 18 and standard deviation of 4. Each BA term is taken as a sample point to identify the required counts (for this specific analysis). A binning of data is performed with the following three bins (which capture the number of learners who follow the instructions in a sample). These bins, divide the solution space into equal areas.  Bin-1: [less than or equal to 35] Bin-2: [36 to less than or equal to 50] Bin-3: [51 to less than or equal to 100]  Given this information, answer the given subquestions

Bin-1: [less than or equal to 35] Bin-2: [36 to less than or equal to 50] Bin-3: [51 to less than or equal to 100]  Given this information, answer the given subquestions
question_texts: The BA discourse is often cluttered with queries / requests related to solutions for Past Year Question Papers (PYQP). The course instructor, Dr. Milo, had been informing that students need to put in effort to find solutions by searching the discourse. However, the results seem to disappointing. Therefore, Dr. Milo wanted to do a few basic analytics on discourse behaviour of students. Past student data was collected for the analysis.  Past data was collected for the BA terms in Jan-2022, May-2022, Sep-2022, Jan-2023, May-2023 and Sep-2023. For each term, 100 randomly selected unique student IDs were sampled. Of the 100 student IDs, 50 were “Male” and the remaining were “Female”. The learners in the discourse have either “followed the instructions” or “not followed the instructions” or “have not accessed the discourse at all” (these three are referred to as access categories). Specifically, for the sample data in the different terms (in sequence of earliest term to later term i.e. Jan-2022 to Sep-2023) it was observed that  1. For the Male sample: 20, 30, 25, 45, 25 and 35 had not followed the instructions (respectively in each term i.e 20 male learners had followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) 2. For the Male sample: 2, 10, 5, 4, 5 and 3 had not accessed discourse at all (respectively in each term i.e 2 male learners had not accessed discourse at all in Jan-2022 term and so on) 3. For the female sample: 15, 22, 32, 25, 20 and 20 had followed the instructions (respectively in each term i.e 15 female learners had followed the instructions in Jan-2022 term and so on) and the rest of the learners in the respective samples had not followed the instructions  Moreover, Dr. Milo assumes that all learners in the “followed the instructions” category are Normally distributed with a mean of 18 and standard deviation of 4. Each BA term is taken as a sample point to identify the required counts (for this specific analysis). A binning of data is performed with the following three bins (which capture the number of learners who follow the instructions in a sample). These bins, divide the solution space into equal areas.  Bin-1: [less than or equal to 35] Bin-2: [36 to less than or equal to 50] Bin-3: [51 to less than or equal to 100]  Given this information, answer the given subquestions

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the **Diploma Level: Business Analytics (Computer-Based Exam)**, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **1. Core Topics & Concepts**
### **A. Statistical Hypothesis Testing**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **p-value**:
   - Probability of observing the sample (or more extreme) **if the null hypothesis (H₀) is true**.
   - **Interpretation**:
     - If **p ≤ α (significance level)**, reject H₀.
     - **Question 2 Answer**: `D` (p-value = chance of observing the sample when H₀ is true).

2. **Chi-Square Goodness-of-Fit Test**:
   - Tests if a sample matches a population distribution.
   - **Test Statistic**:
     \[
     \chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O_i - E_i)^2}{E_i}
     \]
   - **Degrees of Freedom (df)**: `k - 1` (k = categories).

3. **Regression Model Evaluation**:
   - **R² (Coefficient of Determination)**:
     \[
     R^2 = 1 - \frac{SS_{res}}{SS_{tot}} = \frac{SS_{reg}}{SS_{tot}}
     \]
     - **SS_reg**: Explained sum of squares (Regression SS).
     - **SS_tot**: Total sum of squares.
     - **Question 22**: % variability explained = `(Regression SS / Total SS) * 100` → **89.55%** (from `179700.8 / 200679.7`).

   - **Adjusted R²**:
     \[
     \text{Adj } R^2 = 1 - \left( \frac{(1-R^2)(n-1)}{n-p-1} \right)
     \]
     - Penalizes extra predictors.

   - **Standard Error of Regression (S)**:
     \[
     S = \sqrt{\frac{SS_{res}}{n-2}}
     \]
     - Measures average deviation of observations from the regression line.

   - **F-Test (ANOVA)**:
     - Tests if **at least one predictor** is significant.
     - **F-Statistic**:
       \[
       F = \frac{MS_{reg}}{MS_{res}} = \frac{SS_{reg}/p}{SS_{res}/(n-p-1)}
       \]

   - **Question 3**: Adding a variable **does not improve** the model if:
     - **Adjusted R² decreases**.
     - **p-value of the new coefficient > 0.05** (insignificant).
     - **Standard Error increases**.

---

### **B. Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA)**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **Efficiency Measurement**:
   - **Efficiency Score (θ)**: `0 ≤ θ ≤ 1` (1 = fully efficient).
   - **Linear Programming (LP) Formulation**:
     - **Objective**: Maximize efficiency for a **Decision Making Unit (DMU)**.
     - **Constraints**: Weighted outputs ≤ 1, weighted inputs = 1.

2. **Productive Efficiency Frontier**:
   - **Definition**: All combinations where **no output can be increased without reducing another**.
   - **Question 10**: `B` (Productive efficiency frontiers are all combinations where increasing one output requires sacrificing another).

3. **Dual Variables (λ)**:
   - **Interpretation**: Weights assigned to other DMUs in the LP solution.
   - **Question 9**:
     - If **BU6 has θ=1**, it is **efficient**.
     - If **BU5 has θ=0.7**, it is **inefficient**.
   - **Question 16 & 17**:
     - **Sales in BU4** = `(0.35 * Sales_BU4 + 0.4 * Sales_BU5) / Efficiency_BU6`.
     - **Loyal Customers in BU4** = `(0.35 * Loyal_BU4 + 0.4 * Loyal_BU5) / 0.75`.

---

### **C. Conjoint Analysis**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **Part-Worth Utilities**:
   - **Definition**: Utility contribution of **each attribute level**.
   - **Question 7**: `E` (Part-worth = level utilities + utility for that attribute level).

2. **Pairwise Comparisons**:
   - **Number of Unique Pairs**:
     \[
     \text{Pairs} = \frac{n(n-1)}{2}
     \]
     - For **5 products**: `5*4/2 = 10` (**Question 5 Answer: B**).

3. **Regression vs. Optimization Approach**:
   - **Continuous Variables**: Use **optimization** (e.g., linear programming).
   - **Question 6 Answer: C** (Optimization approach for continuous variables).

---

### **D. Probability & Bayesian Inference**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **Bayes’ Theorem**:
   \[
   P(A|B) = \frac{P(B|A) \cdot P(A)}{P(B)}
   \]
   - **Question 13**: Probability product is from **Machine B given defective**:
     \[
     P(B|D) = \frac{P(D|B) \cdot P(B)}{P(D)}
     \]
     - **Given**:
       - `P(B) = 22%`, `P(D|B) = 17%`.
       - `P(D) = Σ P(D|Mi) * P(Mi)` (Law of Total Probability).
     - **Answer**: ~**0.29 (29%)**.

2. **Defective Probability**:
   - **Question 15**: Expected defectives in **10,000 products**:
     \[
     E[\text{Defectives}] = 10000 \times P(D)
     \]
     - **Answer**: ~**1256**.

3. **Non-Defective Probability**:
   - **Question 14**:
     \[
     P(\text{Non-Defective}) = 1 - P(D) \approx 0.87 \text{ (87%)}
     \]

---

### **E. Demand & Revenue Optimization**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **Demand Curve**:
   \[
   Q = 23000 - 10P
   \]
   - **Question 11 (Revenue Maximization)**:
     - **Revenue (R) = P * Q = P*(23000 - 10P)**.
     - **Maximize R**: Take derivative, set to 0.
       \[
       \frac{dR}{dP} = 23000 - 20P = 0 \implies P = 1150
       \]

   - **Question 12 (Profit Maximization)**:
     - **Profit (π) = R - C = (P*Q) - 420*Q**.
     - **Marginal Cost (MC) = 420**.
     - **Optimal P**: Where **Marginal Revenue (MR) = MC**.
       \[
       MR = 23000 - 20P = 420 \implies P = 440
       \]

2. **Price Elasticity of Demand (ED)**:
   \[
   E_D = \frac{\% \Delta Q}{\% \Delta P} = \frac{dQ/dP}{Q/P} = \frac{-10}{Q/P}
   \]
   - **Question 18**:
     - **Demand Equation**: `Q = 912.87 - 3.84P`.
     - **Elasticity at Mean P**:
       \[
       E_D = -3.84 \times \frac{P}{Q} \approx -3.84 \text{ (elastic)}
       \]
     - **Answer**: **3.84** (absolute value).

3. **Market Size (Intercept)**:
   - **Question 19**: Intercept (`912.87`) = **market size when P=0**.

4. **Satiating Price (P when Q=0)**:
   - **Question 20**:
     \[
     0 = 912.87 - 3.84P \implies P = 237.72
     \]

---

### **F. Classification Metrics**
#### **Key Concepts (Questions 29-33):**
1. **Confusion Matrix**:
   |               | **Predicted Loyal** | **Predicted Not Loyal** |
   |---------------|----------------------|-------------------------|
   | **Actual Loyal**      | TP=5                 | FN=2                    |
   | **Actual Not Loyal**  | FP=3                 | TN=2                    |

2. **Metrics**:
   - **Accuracy**:
     \[
     \frac{TP + TN}{TP + TN + FP + FN} = \frac{5 + 2}{12} = 58.33\%
     \]
   - **Precision (Class 1 = Loyal)**:
     \[
     \frac{TP}{TP + FP} = \frac{5}{5 + 3} = 62.5\%
     \]
   - **Recall (Class 1)**:
     \[
     \frac{TP}{TP + FN} = \frac{5}{5 + 2} = 71.43\%
     \]
   - **Precision (Class 0 = Not Loyal)**:
     \[
     \frac{TN}{TN + FN} = \frac{2}{2 + 2} = 50\%
     \]
   - **Recall (Class 0)**:
     \[
     \frac{TN}{TN + FP} = \frac{2}{2 + 3} = 40\%
     \]

---

### **G. Empirical Distributions & Hypothesis Testing**
#### **Key Concepts:**
1. **Empirical Distribution**:
   - Built from **sample data**, **PDF/PMF**, or **summary statistics** (**Question 8**).

2. **Chi-Square Test for Normality**:
   - **Test Statistic**:
     \[
     \chi^2 = \sum \frac{(O_i - E_i)^2}{E_i}
     \]
   - **Degrees of Freedom**: `k - 1 - m` (k = bins, m = estimated parameters).
   - **Question 27**: Test statistic = **1**.
   - **Question 28**: df = **2** (3 bins - 1 - 1 for mean & variance).

3. **Contingency Tables (Chi-Square Test for Independence)**:
   - **Expected Frequency**:
     \[
     E_{ij} = \frac{(\text{Row Total}_i)(\text{Column Total}_j)}{\text{Grand Total}}
     \]
   - **Question 23**: Expected "Female Not Followed" = **27.5**.
   - **Question 24**: Test statistic for male access categories = **~49.33**.

---

### **H. Data Binning**
#### **Key Concepts:**
- **Equal-Area Binning** (Question 25-26):
  - **Bin 1**: `P(X ≤ 35)` = **33.33%**.
  - **Bin 2**: `P(36 ≤ X ≤ 50)` = **33.33%**.
  - **Bin 3**: `P(X ≥ 51)` = **33.33%**.
  - **Observed Frequency (Bin 1)**: **3** (from normal distribution data).
  - **Expected Frequency (Bin 2)**: **2**.

---

## **2. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **Graph 1: Statistical Testing & Regression**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Hypothesis Testing] --> B[p-value]
    A --> C[Chi-Square Test]
    B --> D["Interpretation: p ≤ α → Reject H₀"]
    C --> E["Test Statistic: χ² = Σ(O-E)²/E"]
    A --> F[Regression Analysis]
    F --> G[R² & Adjusted R²]
    F --> H[F-Test]
    F --> I[Standard Error]
    G --> J["R² = 1 - SS_res/SS_tot"]
    H --> K["F = MS_reg/MS_res"]
```

### **Graph 2: DEA & Efficiency**
```mermaid
graph TD
    L[Data Envelopment Analysis] --> M[Efficiency Score θ]
    L --> N[Linear Programming]
    M --> O["θ = 1 → Efficient"]
    M --> P["θ < 1 → Inefficient"]
    N --> Q[Dual Variables λ]
    Q --> R["λ ≠ 0 → Peer Group"]
```

### **Graph 3: Conjoint Analysis**
```mermaid
graph TD
    S[Conjoint Analysis] --> T[Part-Worth Utilities]
    S --> U[Pairwise Comparisons]
    U --> V["Unique Pairs: n(n-1)/2"]
    T --> W["Utility per Attribute Level"]
```

### **Graph 4: Probability & Bayesian Inference**
```mermaid
graph TD
    X[Probability] --> Y[Bayes' Theorem]
    Y --> Z["P(A|B) = P(B|A)P(A)/P(B)"]
    X --> AA[Law of Total Probability]
    AA --> AB["P(B) = Σ P(B|A_i)P(A_i)"]
    X --> AC[Defective Probability]
    AC --> AD["E[Defectives] = N * P(D)"]
```

### **Graph 5: Demand Optimization**
```mermaid
graph TD
    AE[Demand Curve] --> AF["Q = a - bP"]
    AE --> AG[Revenue Maximization]
    AG --> AH["R = P*Q → dR/dP = 0"]
    AE --> AI[Profit Maximization]
    AI --> AJ["π = R - C → MR = MC"]
    AE --> AK[Elasticity]
    AK --> AL["E_D = (dQ/dP)(P/Q)"]
```

### **Graph 6: Classification Metrics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    AM[Confusion Matrix] --> AN[True Positives TP]
    AM --> AO[False Positives FP]
    AM --> AP[True Negatives TN]
    AM --> AQ[False Negatives FN]
    AN --> AR[Precision = TP/(TP+FP)]
    AN --> AS[Recall = TP/(TP+FN)]
    AO --> AT[Accuracy = (TP+TN)/(TP+TN+FP+FN)]
```

### **Graph 7: Hypothesis Testing Workflow**
```mermaid
graph TD
    AU[Empirical Data] --> AV[Chi-Square Test]
    AU --> AW[t-Test]
    AV --> AX["χ² = Σ(O-E)²/E"]
    AW --> AY["t = (x̄ - μ)/(s/√n)"]
    AX --> AZ[Degrees of Freedom]
    AY --> BA[p-value]
    AZ --> BB["df = k-1 (Goodness-of-Fit)"]
    AZ --> BC["df = (r-1)(c-1) (Independence)"]
```
